iti89:4.4: Commentary gives me sutaṁ as variant here. But this construction is found in a number places with vissuta. See MN 86:18.40, Thag 16.8:15.2.
iti89:5.3: Despite its fame, this, together with its parallel at Kd 17:4.8.11, is the only mention of Avīci hell in early Buddhism. It became a standard hell in later texts of the Buddhists (eg. Kv 23.3:1.10, Vb 3:23.4, Cnd 23:44.3) and Brahmans (eg. Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.28). The commentary explains avīci as “without interval”, i.e. “unrelenting”; a similar explanation is cited by Vasubandhu at Abhidharmakośabhāṣya 3.58.
iti89:5.4: Compare the description of hell as “four-doored” at MN 129:16.3 = MN 130:16.3 = AN 3.36:16.1.
